H0.text: Flower takes in minerals and water in a dandelion plant.

H1.text: Leaf is the part of a dandelion plant that takes in minerals and water.

H2.text: Root is the part of a dandelion plant that takes in minerals and water.

H3.text: Stem is the part of a dandelion plant that takes in minerals and water.

A4.text: Raw dandelion greens contain high amounts of vitamins A, C, and K, and are moderate sources of calcium, potassium, iron, and manganese.

A5.text: Its taproot brings up nutrients for shallow-rooting plants.

A6.text: Fine roots: typically primary roots <2 mm diameter that have the function of water and nutrient uptake.

A7.text: Roots are the organs that are modified to provide anchorage for the plant and take in water and nutrients into the plant body, which allows plants to grow taller and faster.
